awd_titl_txt: Conference: Workshop for Rigorous and Reproducible Scientific Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
The workshop explores a rigorous and reproducible approach to the specification, analysis, and validation of scientific workflows by assembling diverse scientists from scientific disciplines such as biology, physics and climate science, along with researchers from formal methods focusing on logic, theorem proving and constraint solving. Fundamental scientific breakthroughs are key to human advancement in diverse areas including agriculture, vaccines, climate prediction and next-generation computers. At the same time, science increasingly relies on enormous volumes of data that are processed through software to provide evidence supporting scientific conclusions. Failure to maintain the highest levels of scientific rigor and reproducibility can lead to a lot of confusion and wasted resources. Above all, this can lead to loss of trust in science and scientists among the public, when this is crucial for making informed policies. The recent spate of high-profile retractions suggests that the process of ensuring rigor and reproducibility is failing to keep pace with the volume of new scientific research. Formal methods, as an area, has successfully tackled the problems of specification and verification in areas including hardware, software, and cyber-physical systems. The workshop, to be held in-person in Boulder, CO, will enable robust conversations to help formal methods experts understand the nature of scientific research workflows while simultaneously exposing scientists to ideas from formal specification, modeling, and verification. In addition, the workshop will include editors from major journals in these areas and participants from government, as they are critical part in the chain of scientific endeavor. 

The workshop’s novelties include a first of its kind meeting between scientists, formal methods experts, and other stakeholders in a bid to spark new ideas and collaborations between participants that address the issue of rigor and reproducibility for scientific workflows. The workshop’s impacts include new ideas that could revolutionize how scientists present the entire scientific workflow from data gathering to the final conclusions in a way that is easy to verify and reproduce. The workshop is an important step towards ensuring that the scientific discoveries of the future are clearly rigorous in a manner that is easy to comprehend, validate and reproduce independently. This will benefit the scientific community and society by building confidence in our basic scientific research. The workshop celebrates diversity in science by involving people from many different backgrounds including under-represented groups in the conversation to shape the future of the scientific research methodology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop on rigorous and reproducible scientific reasoning was held in Boulder, CO, between November 13-14, 2023. This event was part of a series of workshops on `Accelerating Computing-Enabled Discovery (ACED)'', sponsored by the US National Science Foundation (NSF).  R2SR featured nearly 40 in-person participants and a handful of remote participants from around the US with expertise in diverse areas including formal methods, synthetic biology, scientific computing, and climate science. The workshop featured brief theme setting talks followed by three rounds of discussion sessions involving breakout groups of participants. The final round of discussion, involving all participants, revolved around a set of organizing questions posed by the NSF. 

 

After nearly two days of intense discussions about rigor and reproducibility in science, the participants arrived at many important conclusions and recommendations for further actions from the scientific community at large. 

 

The participants concluded that the scientific process works in the large: important breakthroughs are coming out and we are reaping benefits as a society (better vaccines, faster computers and communication and better predictions of long term climate) . Basic fundamental advances in scientific understanding is leading to important applications in all the areas that we have considered for the workshop. Yet, many scientific results fail to be rigorous and reproducible/reusable: this leads to wasted effort (lost funding), and an overall public  loss of trust in scientific results.  Some specific observations included:

  • The volume of scientific publications is way too high and it is hard to maintain rigor and reproducibility in the light of this profusion of publications. Academic processes that evaluate scholarship need to change to emphasize aspects such as quality, rigor and reproducibility rather than mere quantiative metrics of scholarship.
  • The scientific community and funding agencies have not adequately emphasized rigor/reproduciblity nearly enough in judging the outcomes of scientific projects. This is changing thanks to new programs such as ACED. As one participant memorably stated: ``we get the science that we pay for''.
  • Funding mechanisms should support community infrastructure building in a more reliable manner for the longer term. 

 

What kind of technologies can promote rigor/reproducibility?

 
There are many interesting approaches taken by various communities to understand rigor/reproducibility. 

  • Many computer science publications have instituted the idea of an independent reproducibility evaluation of results to place a ``reproducibility badge''  on the publication that marks it as having successfully passed the independent evaluation. This is becoming compulsory for certain kinds of publication.     
  • Journals devoted to software that supports scientific research such as the Journal of Open Source Software provides incentives to scholars whose contributions result in useful and high quality software that can be used by other scientists.   
  • In experimental sciences, software that can help the experimenters document the experimental conditions in an accurate and rigorous manner would be very helpful for reproducing and replicating the results.   
  •  Finally, there are many ways in which formal methods can be used in the process of aiding rigorous science.    This includes ideas ranging from specialized type systems to theorem provers that support formal derivations of mathematical models and support automatic generation of code.    However, scientists do not understand formal methods and it is important that the tools produced by the formal methods community are useful to scientists without asking them to be experts in the area.


Where do we go from here?

 
The participants agreed that rigorous science is a ``social process'' that is adopted by a community of scientists who wish to demonstrate that their research has been performed in a painstaking manner and thus the conclusions need to be taken seriously.  Reproducibility (replicability and reusability) are key so that the community can freely examine the process and try to replicate it in their own laboratories to arrive at similar conclusions. It is important that the stakeholders including funding agencies, scientists, publication venues (journals, conferences) and the evaluators (tenure review committees) all agree on the value of rigorous and reproducible research over mere quantitative measures of scientific productivity.
